msItem.title: Chart of 'natural things' and 'eternal things'
Chart of 'simple medicines'
Definitions of medical terms
msItem.rubric: 3r Termys off spices with exponnynge

msItem.title: Definitions of medical terms
msItem.rubric: 3r Vices of maners wirkyng in þe aspices
msItem.incipit: 3r Addicioun / Substraction / Mediacion - On the ryght haunde

msItem.title: The natural properties of the Twelve Signs of the Zodiac
msItem.rubric: 3r Triplicites qualites et propertees off 12 houses
msItem.incipit: 3r Aries / Leo / Sagittarius - hot and drye Coleric fierie orientall or est attractiff
msItem.explicit: 3r Taurus / Cancer / Virgo / Scorpio / Capricornus / Pisces - ffemynyne sygnes

msItem.title: The astrological houses of the planets
msItem.rubric: 3v Houses of planettes by þe 12 signes

msItem.title: List of the opposing signs
msItem.rubric: 4r The opposicion of Synges

msItem.title: Lists of the 7 natural things, 6 unnatural things, and the 3 things against nature
List of definitions relating to medicine and the human body
msItem.incipit: 4r What naturall þinges: Naturall thynges ordenytht or maketht a body as elementes humors
msItem.explicit: 6r And þou that as the bodye ys gretter than the spryte so the spryte ys gretter than the soulle

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for making medicinal pills and clysters
msItem.rubric: 8r Hereafter foloweþ þe pylles and glysters suche as be nessysary for surgions to knowe
msItem.note: Collection of 51 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating the ague
msItem.rubric: 10r Here begynyeþe medysines for the agewe
msItem.note: Collection of six medical recipes.

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: 10v In the name of god amen I Richard Corpson

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for respiratory and stomach ailments
msItem.rubric: 12r Here begynniþe tysandys for stuffynge in þe longes and for schorteness of wynde
msItem.note: Collection of 9 medical recipes, also inlcuding recipes for stomach ailments.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating stone, colic, and strangury
msItem.rubric: 14r Here begyniþee medysines for the stonne the collycke and strawngwyrye
msItem.note: Collection of 34 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating the hot gout
msItem.rubric: 16r Here begynniþe medicines for þe hoote gowte
msItem.note: Collection of 9 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating the cold gout
msItem.rubric: 17r Here begynnyght medicines for the coulde gowte
msItem.note: Collection of 8 medical recipes.

msItem.title: A medical recipe for treating gout
msItem.rubric: 17r For þe Gowte to take a way þe payne by and bye
msItem.incipit: 17r Take the wheyte off an newe layd egge and bett yt cleyre and do a way the fowme and put þerto as moche tryakell off geyne as a nowtte and bet theym to gyder and make þer off an vngtment þat donne take a pleget off towe and wett yt in whyt wynne and wryng yt owt and make yt plaster whysse and so vsse yt therto etcaetera
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating ulcers and swellings
msItem.rubric: 19r Here begynnyght for all mannere of vlceracions bought olde and newe
msItem.note: Collection of 17 medical recipes; including an attribution: An oyntemente for all manere of akynge vlcers and specially for theym in the feytte secundum petrum.

msItem.title: Collection of repellent medicines
msItem.rubric: 21r Here begniþe repecussiue medicynes
msItem.note: Collection of 12 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for resolvative medicines
msItem.rubric: 22r Here beginniþe resolutiff medicines
msItem.note: Collection of 13 medical recipes; containing a few attributions: a diaquilon Rasis and diaquilon þe whyche is wryten in þe antydottario off nycholas.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for making mollifying medicines
msItem.rubric: 23r Medycynes to molyfye
msItem.note: Collection of 12 medical recipes; including one attribution to Galien [Galen].

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for maturative medicines
msItem.rubric: 24r Here begynnitht maturatyff medicines
msItem.note: Collection of 18 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Unidentified treatise on anatomy
msItem.rubric: 25r The Anothomye of marght of bones and of grystyllys
msItem.incipit: 25r Sytehn that I haue enden the chaptere of the generacion off embryon I thynke with the grace off gode Somdell to declaren in þis chaptere the Anothomye of marght bonys and grystyllys
msItem.explicit: 57r thys endytht the laste chappyter off the secounde dystynccion off þe fyrte [sic] parte off thys compylacion. In the wyche yt y trettyd regulerly by the Anothomye off all thes membres in a manys body in composycion etcaetera
msItem.note: The treatise evidently begins imperfectly, with a reference to a preceding chapter on the formation of the embryo that is not present in the manuscript.
This material can also be found in London, Wellcome Collection, MS 567, ff. 10v-128.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making medical plasters
msItem.rubric: 57v Her begynighte the Emplasteres
msItem.note: Collection of 62 medical recipes; contains attributed recipes called Master Johannes plaster for Concucions in the hedde, M. Brownis plaster goode for dropsye and oþere dyssesys, and M. Robarte Tayllors plaster for Concussions and brussers. These recipes may refer to William Brown, naval surgeon, temp. Henry VIII (c. 1535); and Robert Taylour, one of the four wardens of the Fellowship of Surgeons in late 15th century. See C. H. Talbot and E. A. Hammond, The medical practitioners in medieval England: a biographical register (London: Wellcome Historical Medical Library, 1965), pp. 389-390, and 354.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making spasmadraps
msItem.rubric: 61r Here beginniþe the spassmadrapis
msItem.note: Collection of 8 medical recipes; the last recipe was apparently added at a later time but seemingly by the same hand.

msItem.title: The King's Black Plaster
msItem.rubric: 61r The Kyngis Blacke plaster
msItem.incipit: 61r Take Armoniacke ℥ iiij olium [?] omphansinum ℥ iiij turpentyne ℥ vj gumme elempnij ℥ j rosine pine ℥ x et let all theys boyll off a softe fyer off coles onto yt be tawnye or more sadder lycke pyche
msItem.note: Full transcription; apparently added later but seemingly by the main hand of the manuscript.

msItem.title: The King's White Plaster
msItem.rubric: 61r The Kyngis Whyte plaster
msItem.incipit: 61r Take waxe turpentyne ana li j rosine pine li grouce off Betayn off plantayn off Smallage off eche as moche as schall suffyce and boyll þem onto þe consumyng off þe Jussis
msItem.note: Full transcription; apparently added later but seemingly by the main hand of the manuscript.

msItem.title: Medical recipe attributed to a certain Dr Johnson
msItem.rubric: 61v M. Johnson
msItem.incipit: 61v the [...] deffence xij li. of shepes suyt rosyn ij li. wex j li. mele them ouer a softe fyer then strayne them and stere yt tyll yt be colde this is good in Cold Causes
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for cleansing unguents
msItem.rubric: 61v Here begynniþe þe mundifficatiues et cetera
msItem.note: Collection of 21 recipes; one recipe refers to the Liber Almensoris: Vnguentum viride Almensoris the last recipe was apparently added at a later time but seemingly by the same hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making incarnative medicines
msItem.rubric: 63r Here begynnithe þe Incarnatyues
msItem.note: Collection of 14 medical recipes; one recipe is attributed to a medical practitioner: Gybsons Incarnatiue Gybsons Incarnatiue. This recipe may refer to Thomas Gibson [Gybson], master surgeon, London, early 16th century, and a promiment member of the Barber-Surgeons in London during the reigns of Henry VII and Henry VIII. See C. H. Talbot and E. A. Hammond, The medical practitioners in medieval England: a biographical register (London: Wellcome Historical Medical Library, 1965), p. 345. The last recipe in this collection was apparently added at a later time possibly by the same hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making dessicating medicines
msItem.rubric: 64r Her begynniþe dissicatyue medycines
msItem.note: Collection of 13 medical recipes; containing two recipes that have been attributed to a certain 'Peter' (vnguentum dissicatiuum secundum Petrum). The last recipe is attributed to the (?) Earl of Shrewsbury: My lorde of schrowisseberys dissicatyue The last two recipes were apparently added at a later time but seemingly by the same hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for staunching blood
msItem.rubric: 65r Here beginniþe þe staunnchers off bloude with the retentyues and stryctores and deffencyues
msItem.note: Collection of 22 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Two medical unguents
msItem.rubric: 65v Vnguentum defensiuum
msItem.incipit: 65v Recipe vnguentum populeon li. vj white led lytarge ana li ij oyle li ij wex li s. water of Rossis vyneger vj ℥ camfere and ij - Another - Recipe vnguentum populeon vj ceruce lytarg of lede ana ij li. wex half a pound oyle of Rosses ij li vinegre and rose water - quod sufficit
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making medical balms
msItem.rubric: 66r Here beginniþe þe baymmeys
msItem.note: Collection of 9 medical recipes; includes a recipe entitled: Balsanum artificale secundum Johannem veyverye; the last recipe is entitled: The kynges bawme for woundes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making medical oils
msItem.rubric: 67r Here begynniþe the Oyellys mette for a surgeon to haue
msItem.note: Collection of 11 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating sciatica
msItem.rubric: 68v Her begynniþe medysynes for þe Ciathica
msItem.note: Collection of 10 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making unguents
msItem.rubric: 69v Her begynnyght þe vnguentys
msItem.note: Collection of 14 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Medical unguent
msItem.rubric: 70v Vnguentum apostolorum
msItem.incipit: 70v Recipe Rosyn perrosen wex turpentyne ana ʒ iiij oyle vj ʒverdegrece ana quarter of an ownce oyle of spycke as moche as yow wyll
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating aches
msItem.rubric: 71r Her begynniþe medysynes for al manere off achys
msItem.note: Collection of six medical recipes.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for aches and bruises
msItem.rubric: 71r for ache and bruses that cometh of cold cause
msItem.incipit: 71r Recipe bay leues wormwod ana li. s. Rewe sawge ana li j. grynde yowr herbes in a stone morter smale then ye must haue iij li of shepes suyt most fine shred and a potell of oyle put them all together and set them ouer a softe fyre and let them boyle a lytyll then streyne them and kepe them to vse
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for morbo Appollitano
msItem.rubric: 72r Hereafter folowith medicines pro illo morbo Appollitano
msItem.note: Collection of 11 medical recipes; containing two attributed recipe: Vnguentum variolis secundum forestum and Vnguentum pro morbo appolitano expertum et probabum vlceribus secundum petrum.

msItem.title: Two medical recipe for an ointment for treating French Pox (Syphilis)
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for making caustic medicine
msItem.rubric: 73r Heraftere folowytht þe cawstyckes and þe rebateres
msItem.note: Collection of eight medical recipes. The eight recipe may be incomplete and is crossed out.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes to treat burns
msItem.rubric: 74r Here aftere folowþ þe medicynes for all manner off burnynges and schaldynges
msItem.note: Collection of eleven medical recipes.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for treating burns
msItem.note: The recipes are entitled for brennyng and for a member that ys brent with fyre or scalded wyth oyle.
Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for eye ailments
msItem.rubric: 75r Hereafter folowythe medycynes for dessey in þe yeys
msItem.note: Collection of 14 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for treating eye ailments
msItem.note: Three lines added to the final recipe of the collection of medicines for eye ailments and two new recipes by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for treating eye ailments
msItem.note: Four recipes added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for making medical waters
msItem.rubric: 76r Waters mette for a surgyanne to haue
msItem.note: Collection of 15 recipes; several, including the last three recipes, apparently written at a later time but seemingly by the same hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating morphew
msItem.note: Collection of four recipes for treating morphew (no rubric).

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for stinking breath
msItem.rubric: 78r Here be medycynes for stynkynge bretht
msItem.note: Collection of three medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating dropsy
msItem.rubric: 79r Her begynniþe medisynes for the dropsye
msItem.note: Collection of four medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating jaundice
msItem.rubric: 80r Here begynnyutht medicines for the iawnnes et cetera
msItem.note: Collection of six medical recipes; the sixth recipe written at a later time but by the same hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating jaundice
msItem.rubric: 80v for the Jaundyes
msItem.incipit: 80v Take the rotes of salendyn and the roses of grene madder stamp them with a lytyll ale and gyue the sycke to drynke
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating haemorrhoids
msItem.rubric: 81r Hereafter folowytht medycynes for þe emeroydes
msItem.note: Collection of seven medical recipes. Apparently written at a later time than the other recipe collections in the manusript but by the same hand.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 1-17: hand with a five-pointed star Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 18-81: Jug with crown

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos. The unfoliated flyleaves have been allocated Roman numerals between brackets for the purpose of reference in this electronic catalogue record.

supportDesc.condition: The edges of ff. 1-4 are brittle, featuring various small tears. The outer upper corners of ff. 71-76 are heavily torn.

layout.seg: Ruled in crayon, frame only. Double columns. 58 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: The manuscript has been copied by a single scribe working in a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand with both anglicana and secretary features.
Various recipes have been added by a scribe with a 16th-century hand with both anglicana and secretary features on ff. 61v, 65v, 70v, 74v, 75v, 80v.
Various recipes have been added by one or two scribes with similar 16th-century hands with both anglicana and secretary features on ff. 17r, 71r, 72v, 75v.

decoNote.p: Display script with cadels in dark ink at the beginning of each new recipe collection.
Small (1 line) plain initials in red or blue at the beginning of new recipes.
Line-fillers consisting of diagonal tildes alternating between dark and red ink.
Rubricated headings for new collections and recipes throughout.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.
Regular initials occasionally highligthed with red ink.

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century half white vellum binding with purple paper sides over pasteboards and five raised bands on the spine.
Binding height: 290 mm; width: 200 mm; depth: 20 mm.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 15th or early 16th century
origin.p: The manuscript features additions from the first half of the 16th century).

provenance.p: Richard Corpson (fl. 16th century) Corpson, Richard, fl. 16th century: owned or accessed the manuscript and inscribed his name in a draft sentence in a 16th-century hand on f. 10v: In the name of god amen I Richard Corpson.

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three labels pasted onto the spine (O.9.32), and those of its current and previous classmarks inscribed in brown ink on the inside of the front cover (O.9.32), ff. 1r (I.26 [crossed out], O.16.22 [crossed out], and O.9.32), and 2r (O.16.22 [crossed out]). Its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms and name (Collegium SS. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiensi) pasted on f. 2r.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge

analytic.title: Manuscript Evidence for the Use of Medieval English Scientific and Utilitarian Texts

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Camridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
